poem:
"Seeds of Caution"

In May's eager hands, seedlings spring,
An abundance of life in the warming sting,
Garden redolent with hope and wonder -
Yet, twenty percent will blunder.
A careful dance of growth and rot,
Mixing life's tender lot.
How like a gardener this poet is,
Spilling words in robust bliss,
But for the few that do not bloom,
There is still room.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "No room in your garden for all your crops? Try mixing things up with interplanting Now that we are racing through May, I hope you’re surrounded by seedlings emerging and young plants putting down strong roots. It’s a good idea to sow about 20% more seeds than you have room to grow. I probably sow even more than that out of an abundance of caution and a sprinkling of self-doubt. Principally I do this because". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
